an4.243:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambi, in Ghosita’s Monastery.
an4.243:1.2: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,
an4.243:1.3: “Well, Ānanda, has that disciplinary issue been settled yet?”
an4.243:1.5: Venerable Anuruddha’s pupil Bāhiya remains entirely committed to creating a schism in the Saṅgha.
an4.243:1.6: But Anuruddha doesn’t think to say a single word about it.”
an4.243:2.1: “But Ānanda, since when has Anuruddha been involved in disciplinary issues in the midst of the Saṅgha?
an4.243:2.2: Shouldn’t you, together with Sāriputta and Moggallāna, settle all disciplinary issues that come up?
an4.243:3.1: A bad monk sees four reasons to relish schism in the Saṅgha.
an4.243:3.3: Take an unethical monk, of bad qualities, filthy, with suspicious behavior, underhand, no true ascetic or spiritual practitioner—though claiming to be one—rotten inside, corrupt, and depraved.
an4.243:3.5: ‘Suppose the monks know that I’m a bad monk …
an4.243:3.6: If they’re in harmony, they’ll expel me,
an4.243:3.7: but if they’re divided they won’t.’
an4.243:3.8: A bad monk sees this as the first reason to relish schism in the Saṅgha.
an4.243:4.1: Furthermore, a bad monk has wrong view, he’s attached to an extremist view.
an4.243:4.3: ‘Suppose the monks know that I have wrong view …
an4.243:4.4: If they’re in harmony they’ll expel me,
an4.243:4.5: but if they’re divided they won’t.’
an4.243:4.6: A bad monk sees this as the second reason to relish schism in the Saṅgha.
an4.243:5.1: Furthermore, a bad monk has wrong livelihood and earns a living by wrong livelihood.
an4.243:5.3: ‘Suppose the monks know that I have wrong livelihood …
an4.243:5.4: If they’re in harmony they’ll expel me,
an4.243:5.5: but if they’re divided they won’t.’
an4.243:5.6: A bad monk sees this as the third reason to relish schism in the Saṅgha.
an4.243:6.1: Furthermore, a bad monk desires material possessions, honor, and admiration.
an4.243:6.3: ‘Suppose the monks know that I desire material possessions, honor, and admiration.
an4.243:6.4: If they’re in harmony they won’t honor, respect, revere, or venerate me,
an4.243:6.5: but if they’re divided they will.’
an4.243:6.6: A bad monk sees this as the fourth reason to relish schism in the Saṅgha.
an4.243:6.7: A bad monk sees these four reasons to relish schism in the Saṅgha.”
